avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
avalancheActivity.comment:
Above approximately 1200 m snow fell in the last few days. Several medium-sized and large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls sometimes easily released wind slabs formed. On very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be triggered in deep layers of the snowpack and reach quite a large size.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m, in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In particular very steep sunny slopes as well as wind-loaded slopes: As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more frequent dry and moist avalanches are possible, even large ones.

snowpackStructure.comment:
30 to 50 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls clearly visible wind slabs formed.
(--), in particular on steep shady slopes. Various wind slab layers are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack.
The snowpack remains generally prone to triggering. New snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Especially very steep shady slopes, above approximately 2200 m: Towards its base, the snowpack is unstable.

tendency.highlights: The natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Dry and wet avalanches as the day progresses.
avalancheActivity.comment:
Above approximately 1200 m snow fell in the last few days. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs to be found above all in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain can be released easily or naturally above approximately 2200 m. On very steep slopes the avalanches can be triggered in the various layers of new snow and reach a dangerous size.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection. Several large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.

snowpackStructure.comment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls sometimes large wind slabs formed.
The snowpack remains generally prone to triggering. New snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack.

tendency.highlights: The natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
avalancheActivity.comment:
Above approximately 1200 m snow fell in the last few days. The new snow-covered wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering in particular on steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes above approximately 2200 m. Several medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. On steep shady slopes the avalanches can be released in deep layers of the snowpack and reach large size in some cases.
New snow and wind slabs can over a wide area be released by small loads and reach large size in isolated cases, especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
In particular very steep sunny slopes as well as wind-loaded slopes: Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of solar radiation.

snowpackStructure.comment:
10 to 25 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
Faceted weak layers exist in the bottom section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
The snowpack remains generally prone to triggering. New snow is lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack.

tendency.highlights: With the end of the precipitation, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.
